paper_authors: Allen, M. W.; Baines, S.
paper_title: Manipulating the symbolic meaning of meat to encourage greater acceptance of fruits and vegetables and less proclivity for red and white meat

interventions.intervention_description: Informed participants that previous research had found that people who consume more meat endorse hierarchy and dominance values, whereas people who consume more fruits and vegetables reject hierarchy and dominance values.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants who reduced red meat consumption
Percentage of participants who reduced white meat consumption

paper_authors: Amiot, C. E.; El Hajj Boutros, G.; Sukhanova, K.; Karelis, A. D.
paper_title: Testing a novel multicomponent intervention to reduce meat consumption in young men

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received a presentation on declining meat consumption trends in Canada since 1980 and the negative health, animal welfare, and environmental impacts of meat consumption (including PETA videos). They completed a mind attribution task writing about a cow's thoughts and feelings, received practical tips for planning meat-free meals and making substitutions, and set a monthly goal to reduce, maintain, or increase their meat consumption. Text messages provided ongoing reinforcement with educational information, benefit reminders, and recipe links., Text-messaging reinforcement of the informational and self-monitoring components. The messages sent upbeat and educational information that reminded participants of the benefits of reducing meat consumption and provided them with additional tips and links to recipes.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total meat consumption over two weekdays and one weekend day

paper_authors: Anderson, J.
paper_title: An experimental investigation of the impact of video media on pork consumption

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a video about pigs in animal agriculture on a tablet.
Participants watched a 360 degrees video about pigs in animal agriculture. They wore Samsung headsets, which allow viewers to pan in any direction for the duration of each frame.

outcomes.outcome_description: Frequency of pork consumption over the past 30 days

paper_authors: Anderson, E. C.; Feldman Barrett, L.
paper_title: Affective beliefs influence the experience of eating meat

interventions.intervention_description: Humane farm description of the ham sampled by participants: "This ham was raised on a farm that focused on animal welfare. The animals were allowed to roam in grassy outdoor pastures where they could graze and exercise. The animals were not isolated so were able to engage in social behaviors with other pigs."

Factory farm description for the ham sampled by participants: "This ham was produced at a factory farm that focused on production. The animals were confined to concrete indoor pens where they were unable to lie down or go outside. The animals were isolated so could not engage in social behaviors with other pigs."

outcomes.outcome_description: Likelihood of eating sampled pork again

paper_authors: Bertolaso, C.
paper_title: Investigating the effectiveness of message framing and regulatory fit in increasing positive animal attitude and reducing animal products consumption. a study for animal equality

interventions.intervention_description: Facebook posts showing what farmed animals endure in factory farms. Promotion-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan saves 200 animals per year").
Facebook posts showing what farmed animals endure in factory farms. Prevention-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan prevents 270 animals per year from being killed").
Facebook posts showing the special characteristics of animals presented as unique individuals. Promotion-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan saves 200 animals per year").

Facebook posts showing the special characteristics of animals presented as unique individuals. Prevention-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan prevents 270 animals per year from being killed").

outcomes.outcome_description: Average of five items from the Animal Attitude Scale that reference farmed animals
Frequency of animal product consumption (poultry, fish, beef, pork, eggs, dairy) during the past week

paper_authors: Byrd-Bredbenner, C.; Grenci, A.; Quick, V.
paper_title: Effect of a television programme on nutrition cognitions and intended behaviours

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched the "Lisa the vegetarian" Simpson's episode.

outcomes.outcome_description: Average of three meat attitude items (e.g., there is nothing wrong with eating meat)
Average of three intended behavior items (e.g., I plan to become a vegetarian)

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Caso, D.; Conner, M.
paper_title: Correlational study and randomised controlled trial for understanding and changing red meat consumption: the role of eating identities

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received a daily email to remind them of their goal to monitor their red meat consumption and not exceed 200g per week.

outcomes.outcome_description: Average agreement with three intention items (e.g., I intend to eat less than two medium portions of red meat over the next week)
Average agreement with three affective attitude items (e.g., eating less than two medium portion of red meat in the next weeks is unenjoyable - enjoyable)
Average agreement with three instrumental attitude items (e.g., eating less than two medium portion of red meat in the next weeks is not worthwhile- worthwhile)
Total number of red meat portions weighted by portion size

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Caso, D.; Conner, M.
paper_title: Randomised controlled trial of a text messaging intervention for reducing processed meat consumption: the mediating roles of anticipated regret and intention

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received a daily text message via WhatsApp focused on anticipated regret that urged participants to self-monitor processed meat consumption.

outcomes.outcome_description: Average agreement with three intention items (e.g., in the next week, I intend to not eat more than one portion of processed meat [50 g])
Average agreement with three affective attitude items (e.g., in the next week, not eating more than one portion of processed meat [50 g] is unenjoyable-enjoyable)
Average agreement with three instrumental attitude items (e.g., in the next week, not eating more than one portion of processed meat [50 g] is not worthwhile-worthwhile)
Total number of processed meat portions weighted by portion size

paper_authors: Cooney, N.
paper_title: What elements make a vegetarian leaflet more effective?

interventions.intervention_description: Booklet focusing primarily on cruelty, discussing all farm animals, and why to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on cruelty, discussing only chickens and why to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on cruelty, discussing all farm animals, and how to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on cruelty, discussing only chickens, and how to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing all farm animals, and why to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing only chickens, and why to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing all farm animals, and how to go vegetarian.
Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing only chickens, and how to go vegetarian.

outcomes.outcome_description: Number of meals in a typical week that include beef or pork
Number of meals in a typical week that include chicken or turkey
Number of meals in a typical week that include fish
Number of meals in a typical week that include eggs
Average number of meals in a typical week that include animal products (red meat, poultry, fish, eggs)

paper_authors: Rocha Possidónio da Silva, C.
paper_title: Am I too cute to eat? The effect of cuteness appeal on the promotion of a more plant-based diet

interventions.intervention_description: A picture of a high-cuteness pig together with three different pork-meals.
A picture of a low-cuteness pig together with three different pork-meals.

outcomes.outcome_description: Valence of the pork meal shown in an image
Desire to eat the pork meal shown in an image
Willingness to reduce meat consumption
Willingness to avoid eating meat
Willingness to follow a plant-based diet

paper_authors: Doebel, S.; Gabriel, S.; The Humane League
paper_title: Does encouraging the public to “eat vegan,” “eat vegetarian,” “eat less meat,” or “cut out or cut back on” meat and other animal products lead to the most diet change?

interventions.intervention_description: A booklet that discussed the cruelty of animal farming and the health benefits of of removing animal products from one's diet and encouraged the reader to go vegan.
A booklet that discussed the cruelty of animal farming and the health benefits of of removing animal products from one's diet and encouraged the reader to go vegetarian.
A booklet that discussed the cruelty of animal farming and the health benefits of of removing animal products from one's diet and encouraged the reader to eat less meat.

A booklet that discussed the cruelty of animal farming and the health benefits of of removing animal products from one's diet and encouraged the reader to cut out or cut back on meat and other animal products.

outcomes.outcome_description: Number of meals that contain beef or pork in a typical week
Number of meals that contain chicken or turkey in a typical week
Number of meals that contain fish in a typical week
Number of meals that contain eggs in a typical week

Average number of meals that include animal products (beef, pork, chicken, turkey, fish, eggs, dairy) in a typical week

paper_authors: Fehrenbach, K. S.
paper_title: Designing messages to reduce meat consumption: A test of the extended parallel process model

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a 7-minute video that informed viewers of the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) and suggested easy ways to reduce their meat consumption to increase perceived efficacy.

Participants watched a 4-minute video containing the same information about the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) along with the recommended action to eat less meat, but it only included a very minor efficacy component in the conclusion.

outcomes.outcome_description: Intention to eat less meat in the next seven days
Average attitude towards changing diet based on seven dimensions (e.g., bad/good, negative/positive, harmful/beneficial)

paper_authors: Flens, G.; Moleman, P.; de Rooy, L.
paper_title: The effectiveness of leafletting on reducing the consumption of animal products in dutch students

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received a leaflet "​Maak het Verschil"​, a Dutch translation of a highly popular leaflet distributed by Vegan Outreach, Compassionate Choices.

outcomes.outcome_description: Change in chicken consumption in the last 3 months
Change in beef consumption in the last 3 months
Change in pork consumption in the last 3 months
Change in fish consumption in the last 3 months
Change in dairy consumption in the last 3 months

paper_authors: Loy, L. S.; Wieber, F.; Gollwitzer, P. M.; Oettingen, G.
paper_title: Supporting sustainable food consumption: Mental contrasting with implementation intentions (mcii) aligns intentions and behavior

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read a text providing information about meat consumption, adressing environmental consequences of meat consumption and other arguments for reduced consumption.

Participants read a text providing information about meat consumption, adressing environmental consequences of meat consumption and other arguments for reduced consumption. Participants completed a procedure for mental contrasting with implementation intentions in which individuals wrote down (1) a personal goal, (2) positive outcomes of goal achievement, the best outcome, and respective associations, (3) obstacles of goal achievement, their two main obstacles, and respective associations, and finally (4) four IIs addressing their two main obstacles.

outcomes.outcome_description: Change in weight of meat consumed for each meal

paper_authors: Novotná, A.
paper_title: The influence of movie on behavioral change in individual meat and dairy products consumption

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched "Babe: The gallant pig", a movie about a pig who wants to become a sheepdog.
Participants watched "The Ghost in Our Machine", a movie about the animal rights activist and photographer Jo-Ann McArthur.

Participants read a persuasive essay describing health issues of meat consumption.

Participants watched a slideshow that included images and short paragraphs of animal welfare concerns related to meat.

paper_authors: Sparkman, G.; Walton, G. M.
paper_title: Dynamic norms promote sustainable behavior, even if it is counternormative

interventions.intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Recent research has shown that, in the last 5 years, 30% of Americans have now started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people have changed their behavior and begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would."
Partcipants saw the message: "Recent research has shown that 30% of Americans make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people eat less meat than they otherwise would."

outcomes.outcome_description: Interest in eating less meat

interventions.intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Some people are starting to limit how much meat they eat. This is true both nationally and here at Stanford. Specifically, recent research has shown that, over the last 5 years, 30% of Americans have started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people have changed their behavior and begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would."

Partcipants saw the message: "Some people limit how much meat they eat. This is true both nationally and here at Stanford. Specifically, recent research has shown that 30% of Americans make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people eat less meat than they otherwise would."

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of purchased meals containing meat

Participants saw a photo of a cow with a short statement saying that the cow will be sent to the abattoir tomorrow.

paper_authors: Schwitzgebel, E.; Cokelet, B.; Singer, P.
paper_title: Do ethics classes influence student behavior? Case study: Teaching the ethics of eating meat

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read James Rachels' article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism” and were also encouraged to view, on their own outside of class, an optional eleven-minute vegetarianism advocacy video “What Came Before”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants buying a meal containing meat with a restaurant voucher
Percentage of main meals containing meat purchased at the univerity's dining hall

paper_authors: Mathur, M. B.; Peacock, J. R.; Robinson, T. N.; Gardner, C. D.
paper_title: Effectiveness of a theory-informed documentary to reduce consumption of meat and animal products: Three randomized controlled experiments

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. Each segment was followed by free-response questions about the content presented. After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total weight of animal product consumption over the past week

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. Each segment was followed by free-response questions about the content presented. After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.

outcomes.outcome_description: Change in animal product consumption over the next 7 days

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. Each segment was followed by free-response questions about the content presented. After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total weight of animal product consumption over the past week

paper_authors: Reinholdsson, T.; Hedesström, M.; Ejelöv, E.; Hansla, A.; Bergquist, M.; Svenfelt, Å.; Nilsson, A.
paper_title: Nudging green food: The effects of a hedonic cue, menu position, a warm-glow cue, and a descriptive norm

interventions.intervention_description: The digital menu included the message “Many here choose green!” next to the "green food category", which was accompanied by a minimalistic illustration of three people.
The icon representing the “green” food category was moved from the sixth position in the grid of icons in the digital menu (out of 10) to the first position.
The digital menu included the message  “The green option feels good!” which was accompanied by a happy emoji with a halo, conveying a sense of feeling good by doing good.
The digital menu included the message “The green option tastes good!” which was accompanied by an emoji with its tongue on one side of its mouth, conveying a sense of tastiness and fun.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian sales

paper_authors: Caso, G.; Rizzo, G.; Migliore, G.; Vecchio, R.
paper_title: Loss framing effect on reducing excessive red and processed meat consumption: Evidence from Italy

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read that "The World Health Organization (WHO) classified red meat as a possible carcinogen, meaning it could cause cancer. Based on estimates from the Global Disease Burden Project, the WHO states that >34.000 cancer deaths per year worldwide are attributable to high intake of processed meat, while the total number of deaths attributable to a diet rich in red meat was 644.000."

Participants read that "The World Health Organization (WHO) classified red meat as a possible carcinogen, meaning it could cause cancer. Just 50 g of red or processed meat consumed in a regular daily diet can increase cancer incidence by 18%. It is known that high consumption of red or processed meat can increase the risk of other chronic diseases (such as stroke and type II diabetes)."

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants intending to consume less red and processed meat in the future

paper_authors: Oktar, K.; Lerner, A.; Malaviya, M.; Lombrozo, T.
paper_title: Philosophy instruction changes views on moral controversies by decreasing reliance on intuition

interventions.intervention_description: Participants attended a moral philosophy course in which various controversial topics, including meat eating, were discussed. They read Alastair Norcross' Puppies, Pigs, and People. Participants were also instructed to reflect on their views as an additional manipulation.
Participants attended a moral philosophy course in which various controversial topics, including meat eating, were discussed. They read Alastair Norcross' Puppies, Pigs, and People.

outcomes.outcome_description: Agreement with 'To what extent do you find meat-eating morally acceptable or morally wrong?'

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Bertolotti, M.; Catellani, P.
paper_title: Informational and emotional daily messages to reduce red and processed meat consumption

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received daily persuasive messages that cited the health and environmental outcomes of red processed meat cosumption. The information was presented in a way that was meant to evoke anticipated regret (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red/processed meat, you could feel regret for not protecting your health from cancer and the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”).
Participants received daily persuasive messages that cited the health and environmental outcomes of red processed meat cosumption.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total number of processed red meat portions weighted by portion size

paper_authors: Piester, H. E.; DeRieux. C. M.; Tucker, J.; Buttrick, N. R.; Galloway,, J. N.; Wilson, T. D.
paper_title: “I’ll try the veggie burger ”: Increasing purchases of sustainable foods with information about sustainability and taste

interventions.intervention_description: Participants saw a menu of 34 items divided into four categories (appetizers, entrees, “design your own bowl”, and salads), with text at the top of the menu reading, “Sustainability Rankings at the [name of café]". The leaf rating that accompanies each menu item represented the sustainability of each item.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing a sustainable menu item

interventions.intervention_description: Participants saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Sustainable Choice.” The text on this screen read, “Many people don’t know how much our food choices impact the environment. Eating sustainable foods is a good way we can fight climate change! The Garden Fresh Veggie Burger is an especially sustainable choice. Consider giving the Garden Fresh Veggie Burger a try today!”

Participants saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Student Choice.” The text on the screen read, “The garden fresh veggie burger is a tasty choice! In a taste test we did at the [name of caf´e], 95% of people said that the veggie burger tasted good or very good! Consider giving the garden fresh veggie burger a try today!”

Participants saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Student Choice.” The text on the screen read, “The garden fresh veggie burger is a tasty choice! In a taste test we did at the [name of caf´e], 95% of people said that the veggie burger tasted good or very good! Consider giving the garden fresh veggie burger a try today!”. They also saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Sustainable Choice.” The text on this screen read, “Many people don’t know how much our food choices impact the environment. Eating sustainable foods is a good way we can fight climate change! The Garden Fresh Veggie Burger is an especially sustainable choice. Consider giving the Garden Fresh Veggie Burger a try today!”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants buying a veggie burger
Percentage of participants buying a vegetarian menu item

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Climatarian diet significantly reducing or eliminating red meat from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Livestock agriculture contributes up to a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions, with almost all of this coming from cows and sheep. In Australia, producing 1 kg of beef requires an average of 15,182 L of water. Furthermore, livestock agriculture drives 80% of deforestation worldwide, using up a third of the world s ice-free land. Adopting a Climatarian diet is a powerfulway to reduce your impact on the climate. Shifting to a Climatarian diet will reduce your carbon footprint by approximately 1000 kg of CO2 every year, or the equivalent of driving from Perth to Brisbane."

Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is the ‘One step for the animals diet' eliminating chicken from our diets. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. The vast majorityof these animals today are birds. It takes more than 200 chickens to provide the same number of meals as one cow.If we can convince someone to stop eating birds, they would go from being responsible for the factory farming and slaughtering of more than two dozen land animals per year to fewer than one. Furthermore, while most cows and sheep raised in Australia spend most of their life grazing, the vast majority of chickens are raised in crowded factory farms."

Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Reducetarian diet reducing the amount of meat that we eat. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factoryfarms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a reductionist diet is appealing because not everyone is willing to follow an all-or-nothing diet. It is also a powerful way to reduce animal cruelty. For example, halving your meat consumption will spare around 50 innocent lives every year. This includes about 13 land animals, and 37 fish and shellfish every year."

Participants read:  "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Vegetarian diet eliminating all meat and fish from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a vegetarian diet is the most powerful way to object to animal cruelty, and by doing so, you will spare approximately 100 animal lives (25 land animals and 75 fish and shellfish) every year."

outcomes.outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Piazza, J.; Gregson, R.; Kordoni, A.; Pfeiler, T. M.; Ruby, M. B.; Ellis, D. A.; Sahin, E.; Reith, M.
paper_title: Monitoring a meat-free pledge with smartphones: An experimental study

interventions.intervention_description: Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.

Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.

Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.

outcomes.outcome_description: Daily consumption of beef, pork, chicken, turkey, and other meats

paper_authors: Schwitzgebel, E.; Cokelet, B.; Singer, P.
paper_title: Students Eat Less Meat After Studying Meat Ethics

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read James Rachels’ article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism”. Teaching assistants played the 11-minute vegetarianism advocacy video “What Came Before” that contained factory farm footage. They also presented both pro and con considerations in their discussion sections, encouraging debate among students.

Participants read James Rachels’ article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism”. Teaching assistants presented both pro and con considerations in their discussion sections, encouraging debate among students.

outcomes.outcome_description: Agreement with 'Eating the meat of factory farmed animals is unethical.'
Agreement with 'For at least the next month, I will eat no factory farmed meat at all – or if I find it too difficult to stick to that, I will eat it at most once per week.'

paper_authors: Gunther, O. E.; MacInnisa, C. C.; Hodson, G.; Dhont, K.
paper_title: Addressing Behavior and Policy Around Meat: Associating Factory Farming with Animal Cruelty “Works” Better than Zoonotic Disease

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read a brief paragraph that highlighted the connections between zoonotic diseases and factory farming.
Participants read a brief paragraph that highlighted the connections between animal cruelty and factory farming.

outcomes.outcome_description: Average attitude towards current meat consumption (e.g., to what extent do you want to reduce your consumption of animal products from factory farms?)

paper_authors: Kurz, V.
paper_title: Nudging to reduce meat consumption: Immediate and persistent effects of an intervention at a university restaurant

interventions.intervention_description: A vegetarian dish was listed as the first item on the menu and was also made visible to customers at the counter

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian dish sales

paper_authors: Andersson, A.; Nelander, L.
paper_title: Nudge the lunch: A field experiment testing menu-primacy effects on lunch choices

interventions.intervention_description: A vegetarian dish was listed as the first item on the menu.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian dish sales

paper_authors: Branković, M.; Budžak, A.; Tulić, N.; Janković, J.
paper_title: Effects of experimentally induced self-affirmation on the openness to meat reduction and alternative protein sources

interventions.intervention_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of 10 values and briefly describe a situation or example that shows how the first-ranked value is reflected in their personal experience. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.

Participants were asked to create a ranked list of 10 values and briefly describe a situation or example that shows how the first-ranked value is reflected in their group experience. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.

outcomes.outcome_description: Average openness to meat reduction measured with five items (e.g. their readiness to reduce meat consumption in the following 6 months)

paper_authors: Venema, T. A. G.; Holm Jensen, N.
paper_title: We meat again: a field study on the moderating role of location-specific consumer preferences in nudging vegetarian option

interventions.intervention_description: "Chef’s recommendation" stickers were placed on the vegetarian sandwich bags. One vegetarian sandwich was displayed on a plate at eye-level with the content clearly visible. This plate was accompanied by a sign that read “Kokken anbefaler” (Chef's recommendation) and a brief description of the café’s sustainability goals. All vegetarian sandwiches were placed in first line-of-sight from the typical customer flow direction. The labels on vegetarian sandwiches were slightly more colourful and the bags were closed more aesthetically than meat sandwiches.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian sandwich sales

paper_authors: Guedes, D.; Brazão, V.; Roque, L; Campos, L.; Godinho, C.; Truninger, M.; Vinnari, M.; João Graça, J.
paper_title: Promoting plant-based eating in meat-centric meal contexts: a field study

interventions.intervention_description: A 2-day workshop with the canteen kitchen staff on the relevance of promoting plant-based eating, basic principles of plant-based nutritional literacy, and practical demonstrations of how to improve the visual and sensory appeal of plant-based meals was conducted. Posters advertising the "Sustainability Week" initiative were placed in the cafeteria. The menu presented the vegetarian option as the "suggestion of the day" with an increased font size above the meat and fish options.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian lunch sales

paper_authors: Garnett, E. E; Marteau, T. M.; Sandbrook, C.; Pilling, M. A.; Balmford, A.
paper_title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales

interventions.intervention_description: Students passed by a vegetarian option first the cafeteria.
Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.
Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian meal sales

interventions.intervention_description: Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.
Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian meal sales

paper_authors: Winkelmair, A.; Jansen, P.
paper_title: The positive impact of mindfulness interventions on the explicit and implicit affective attitudes toward vegetarian foods

interventions.intervention_description: Participants completed a 12-week compassion and cating-based training which consisted of weekly sessions á 75 min and weekly homework assignments. Participants were introduced to a way to offer love to themselves, other people, or animals. Affect dyad situations were applied where partners sit face to face, and one partner contemplates a situation to a specific theme of the main topics. The other partner listens attentively without giving any verbal or non-verbal feedback.

Participants completed a 12-week mindfulness-based stress reduction program that included various elements of meditation: body scan, mindful eating, emphasizing the breath, and sitting and walking meditation training. Every session contained a talk about specific topics such as different forms of meditation and problems that may arise with them. The focus of this mindfulness group was on the rather cognitive elements of mindfulness and its qualities of awareness.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants identifying as vegan or vegetarian

paper_authors: Pohlmann, A.
paper_title: The taste of compassion: Influencing meat attitudes with interhuman and interspecies moral appeals

interventions.intervention_description: With a visible timer counting down from 3 min, participants were asked to recall 10 behaviors where they acted “particularly masculine/manly” or “particularly feminine/womanly” (depending on their gender). Participants read that men and women can easily recall 12 behaviors. The task is intentionally difficult with the purpose of leading participants to infer that their performance is below purportedly acceptable standards for their respective gender, thus threatening gender identity. Then, participants were asked to evaluate photographic art prints that a restaurant is considering exhibiting in its dining areas: participants viewed a slideshow consisting of 15 pretested stock photographs portraying scenes of vulnerability, human connection, care-giving, and displays of emotional distress. The photos pictured female and male adults, as well as children and the elderly, and a range of ethnicities.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants selecting a meat entrée out of ten pairs of photographs of popular entrées that can be prepared with meat or in a vegetarian version

interventions.intervention_description: Installation of of visual manipulations under the guise of a photo exhibit at the restaurant. The photographic stimuli were chosen with the following in mind: the connection between human and animal needed to be emphasized by visual overlap between the subjects, suggesting a caring, devoted, and protecting attitude.

outcomes.outcome_description: Number of meat menu item sales

interventions.intervention_description: All participants completed an essay task that threatened gender identity and subsequently watched a slideshow. Compassion was primed a slideshow using photographs showing people as having a caring, devoted, and protecting attitude. Participants then reviewed ingredients and nutritional information for the BLT, chicken, and falafel wrap presented in standard FDA tables.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing a wrap containing meat (BLT or chicken) over a falafel wrap

paper_authors: Marcone, A. L.; Darmstadt, G. L.; Challamel, G. A.; Mathur, M.; Gardner, C. D.
paper_title: Effects of an educational planetary plate graphic on meat consumption in a Stanford University dining hall: a randomized controlled trial

interventions.intervention_description: Signs with a Planetary Health Plate graphic featuring a diet based on the EAT Lancet Planetary Health Diet were posted. The sign included information on top of the sign: “Today, our diets have a large impact on our global ecosystem. In February 2019, scientists collaborated with The Lancet medical journal to establish this realistic diet that maintains both human and planetary health.” And on the bottom of the sign “Modeling your plate like this one builds a healthy diet and a sustainable world”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Number of meat-dish servings

paper_authors: Slapø, H. B.; Karevold, K. I.
paper_title: Simple Eco-Labels to Nudge Customers Toward the Most Environmentally Friendly Warm Dishes: An Empirical Study in a Cafeteria Setting

interventions.intervention_description: All meat dishes were labeled as “High CO2” dishes, all fish dishes as “Medium CO2”, and all vegetarian as “Low CO2” dishes.
The vegetarian dish was labeled with the “Low CO2” sign.
The meat dish was labeled with a “High CO2” sign.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian dish sales

paper_authors: Boronowsky, R. D.; Zhang, A. W.; Stecher, C.; Presley, K.; Mathur, M.; Cleveland, D. A.; Garnett, E.; Wharton, C.; Brown, D.; Meier, A.; Wang, M.; Braverman, I; Jay, J. A.
paper_title: Plant-based default nudges effectively increase the sustainability of catered meals on college campuses: Three randomized controlled trials

interventions.intervention_description: Individuals responded to an RSVP survey for an event in which the vegetarian option was the default meal preference.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian meal selections

paper_authors: Banach, N.; Stel, M
paper_title: Reducing Speciesism: An Intervention to Change People’s Attitudes and Behavioral Intentions

interventions.intervention_description: A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.

outcomes.outcome_description: Score on the Speciesism Scale (e.g., morally, animals always count for less than humans)
Intention to change behaviors that (in)directly harm animals across five categories (e.g., entertainment, experiments, farming)
Willingness to sign a fictitious animal rights petition that promoted giving animals the same rights as humans

interventions.intervention_description: A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.

outcomes.outcome_description: Score on the Speciesism Scale (e.g., morally, animals always count for less than humans)
Intention to change behaviors that (in)directly harm animals across five categories (e.g., entertainment, experiments, farming)
Willingness to sign a fictitious animal rights petition that promoted giving animals the same rights as humans

paper_authors: Gravert, C.; Kurz, V.
paper_title: Nudging à la carte: a field experiment on climate-friendly food choice

interventions.intervention_description: The menu listed the daily vegetarian and fish dishes but not the meat dish and a sentence stated that “an option containing meat is available on request.”

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian meal selections

paper_authors: Erhard, A.;  Boztuğ, Y.; Lemken, D.
paper_title: How do defaults and framing influence food choice? An intervention aimed at promoting plant-based choice in online menus

interventions.intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the plant-based default condition, the plant-based sausage was selected.

Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the sustainable plant-based default condition, the plant-based sausage was selected and a pop-up message said "We have selected the most sustainable sausage for you”.

Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the tasty plant-based default conditions, the plant-based sausage was selected and a pop-up message said "We have selected the tastiest sausage for you”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of times a meal with the plant-based sausage was selected in a mock meal-kit delivery service

paper_authors: Bianchi, F.; Stewart, C.; Astbury, N. M.; Cook, B.; Aveyard, P.; Jebb, S. A.
paper_title: Replacing meat with alternative plant-based products (RE-MAP): a randomized controlled trial of a multicomponent behavioral intervention to reduce meat consumption

interventions.intervention_description: The intervention consisted of 4 components: 1) free meat substitutes for the household for 4 weeks; 2) information leaflets about the health and environmental benefits of eating less meat; 3) recipes; and 4) success stories in the form of vignettes of people who reduced their meat intake.

outcomes.outcome_description: Daily meat consumption
Intention to eat low-meat diet
Attitudes towards eating a low-meat diet
Score on the Meat Attachment Questionnaire (e.g., I love meals with meat)
Percentage of participants identifying as vegan or vegetarian

paper_authors: Perino, G.; Schwirplies, C.
paper_title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "Meat harms your health"). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "A little less meat on plates would help protect the climate more than many people think."). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "All scientific findings prove that animals are social creatures, capable of suffering"). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

outcomes.outcome_description: Intention to reduce meat consumption by a little or a lot in the coming weeks

paper_authors: Çoker, E. N.; Pechey, R.; Frie, K.; Jebb, S. A.; Stewart, C.; Higgs, S.; Cook, B.
paper_title: A dynamic social norm messaging intervention to reduce meat consumption: A randomized cross-over trial in retail store restaurants

interventions.intervention_description: The message “More and more [retail store name] customers are choosing our veggie options” appeared in a green circle on the top right corner of the image displayed on the digital boards, covering 1/8th of the screen, and was animated with a small stretching and wobbling effect to draw customers’ attention further. The message was displayed alongside a picture of the vegetarian breakfast option during the breakfast service hours, and a vegetarian main meal during the remaining trading hours.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of main meals that were plant-based

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Catellania, P.; Casob, D.; Conner, M.
paper_title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits

interventions.intervention_description: A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the health condition received messages focused on the health benefits of eating little red, processed meat (e.g. “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect your health from colon cancer/heart disease/respiratory disease).

A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the environment condition participants received messages focused on the environmental benefits of eating little red, processed meat (e.g., “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases/soil acidification/climate change”).

A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the health + environment condition participants received a combination of the two messages on eating little red, processed meat (e.g., “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect your health from colon cancer/heart disease/respiratory disease, and at the same time you will protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases/soil acidification/ climate change”).

outcomes.outcome_description: Number of red and processed meat servings over the previous week

paper_authors: Garnett, E. E.; Balmford, A; Marteau, T. M.; Pilling, M. A.; Sandbrook, C.
paper_title: Price of change: Does a small alteration to the price of meat and vegetarian options affect their sales?

interventions.intervention_description: The college cafeteria decreased the price of the vegetarian option by 20 pence (from £2.05 to £1.85) and increased the price of meat options by 20 pence (from £2.52 to £2.72).

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of main meals that were vegetarian
Percentage of main meals that were meat-based

paper_authors: Hughes, J. P.; Weick, M.; Vasiljevic, M.
paper_title: Can environmental traffic light warning labels reduce meat meal selection? A randomised experimental study with UK meat consumers

interventions.intervention_description: The meat option was labeled with a red “High Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegetarian and vegan options were labeled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label

The meat option was labeled with a red “High Climate Impact” traffic light warning label. The vegetarian and vegan options were labeled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label. There was also an orange“Medium Climate Impact” traffic light warning label presented for the fish option.
The meat burger was labeled with a red “High Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegetarian burger was labeled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegan option was labelled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of times participants selected the meat option
Desire to eat and perceived appeal of a meat burger
Likelihood of buying and eating a meat burger in the next four weeks
Desire to eat and perceived appeal of a vegetarian burger
Likelihood of buying and eating a vegetarian burger in the next four weeks
Desire to eat and perceived appeal of a vegan burger
Likelihood of buying and eating a vegan burger in the next four weeks

paper_authors: Saulais, L.;Massey, C; Perez-Cueto, F. J. A.; Appleton, K. M.; Dinnella, C.; Monteleone, E.; Depezay, L.; Hartwell, H.; Giboreau, A.
paper_title: When are “Dish of the Day” nudges most effective to increase vegetable selection?

interventions.intervention_description: The vegetarian option (veggie burger) was labeled as the dish of the day
The vegetarian option (veggie burger) was labeled as the dish of the day

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of customers choosing the vegetarian dish advertised as the dish of the day

paper_authors: Karakaş, N., Jaeger, B.
paper_title: Changes in attitudes toward meat consumption after chatting with a large language model

interventions.intervention_description: Participants had an open-ended chat about meat consumption that lasted 5-10 minutes with ChatGPTT-4o. The same initial prompt was entered for all participants: “I want to have a conversation about meat consumption. I currently eat meat. Are there any reasons why I should limit my meat consumption or stop eating meat entirely?”. Participants were given a list of questions they could ask ChatGPT, but were also told that they could decide where to steer the conversation. The provided questions focused on the environment (e.g., “How does meat consumption impact the environment?”), personal health (e.g., “Is it necessary to eat meat to be healthy?”), and animal welfare (e.g., “What percentage of meat in Dutch supermarkets comes from factory farms?”), and also included more generic prompts (e.g., “It would be quite difficult to reduce my meat consumption by a lot. How can I make this easier?”).

outcomes.outcome_description: Average score on the Meat Commitment Scale

paper_authors: Anderson, J.
paper_title: “Reduce” Or “Go Veg”? Effects On Meal Choice

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a video describing the diverse benefits of plant-based eating, showed some mild factory farm footage, and described changing social norms around meat consumption to convey a growing trend. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to reduce their meat consumption.

Participants watched a video describing the diverse benefits of plant-based eating, showed some mild factory farm footage, and described changing social norms around meat consumption to convey a growing trend. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to adopt a vegetarian diet.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of meatless meal orders
Agreement with 'Are you willing to pledge to reduce the amount of meat you eat?'
Agreement with 'Are you willing to pledge to stop eating meat?'

paper_authors: Abrahamse, W.; Steg, L.; Vlek, C.; Rothengatter, T.
paper_title: The effect of tailored information, goal setting, and tailored feedback on household energy use, energy-related behaviors, and behavioral antecedents

interventions.intervention_description: Two groups of households received tailored energy-saving information, including details about global warming and energy costs, plus a personalized list of relevant energy-saving measures. Both groups were asked to achieve a 5% energy reduction and received individual feedback via a website showing their percentage energy savings, the contribution of each behavior, and money saved. The first group received only individual goals and feedback, while the second group also received a collective 5% group goal and monthly feedback about the group's average and total energy savings via newsletter.

outcomes.outcome_description: Meat consumption per meal

paper_authors: Acharya, S.; Maskarinec, G.; Williams, A. E.; Oshiro, C.; Hebshi, S.; Murphy, P.
paper_title: Nutritional changes among premenopausal women undertaking a soya based dietary intervention study in Hawaii

interventions.intervention_description: Regular supplies of soya foods were given free-of-charge to the intervention group. Based on individual preferences, the study dietitian made speciﬁc suggestions on how to incorporate soya foods into the daily menu, such as replacing meat with tofu in stew or fried dishes, cow milk with soyamilk, and cookies with a soya protein bar. To avoid weight gain, replacing other foods was emphasized over adding soya foods. To maintain compliance, all participants received individual dietary counselling by a registered dietitian and follow-up phone calls. They had at least six contacts with the dietitian during the ﬁrst year and were counselled on how to maintain a healthy diet according to the food guide pyramid.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total dairy servings consumed during the previous day
Milk servings consumed during the previous day
Yoghurt servings consumed during the previous day
Cheese servings consumed during the previous day
Meat, poultry, and fish servings consumed during the previous day
Red meat servings consumed during the previous day
Processed meat servings consumed during the previous day
Poultry servings consumed during the previous day
Fish servings consumed during the previous day
Eggs servings consumed during the previous day

paper_authors: Egeler, G.; Baur, P.
paper_title: Menüwahl in der Hochschulmensa : Fleisch oder Vegi? Ergebnisse eines 12-wöchigen Feldexperiments

interventions.intervention_description: 33% of the meals offered in the cafeteria contained meat

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of dishes sold containing meat (excluding fish)
Percentage of dishes sold containing fish
Percentage of dishes sold that were vegetarian (excluding vegan)
Percentage of dishes sold that were vegan

paper_authors: Tschümperlin, M.
paper_title: Nudging – ein leichter Stups in Richtung weniger Fleisch
